Inquiry"],"published-print":{"date-parts":[[2022,4]]},"abstract":"<jats:title>Abstract<\/jats:title><jats:p>We explore whether COVID\u201019 disproportionately affected women in the labor market using <jats:italic>Current Population Survey<\/jats:italic> data through the end of 2020. We find that male\u2013female gaps in the employment\u2010to\u2010population ratio and hours worked for women with school\u2010age children have widened but not for those with younger children. Triple\u2010difference estimates are consistent with most of the reductions observed for women with school\u2010age children being attributable to additional childcare responsibilities (the \u201cCOVID motherhood penalty\u201d). Conducting decompositions, we find women had a greater likelihood to telework, higher education levels and a less\u2010impacted occupational distribution, which all contributed to lessening negative impacts relative to men.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.1111\/ecin.13054","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2022,1,6]],"date-time":"2022-01-06T05:01:45Z","timestamp":1641445305000},"page":"485-507","update-policy":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1002\/crossmark_policy","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":53,"title":["The evolving impacts of the COVID\u201019 pandemic on gender inequality in the US labor market: The COVID motherhood penalty"],"prefix":"10.1111","volume":"60","author":[{"given":"Kenneth
